snippet: This time Russian warplanes may have struck an ISIS-held town as well as anti-government insurgents.

byline.contributor: Anne Barnard reported from Beirut, and Andrew E. Kramer from Moscow. Reporting was contributed by Michael R. Gordon from New York; Hwaida Saad and Maher Samaan from Beirut; and Neil MacFarquhar from Moscow.
byline.original: By ANNE BARNARD and ANDREW E. KRAMER

abstract: Russian warplanes target Syrian rebel coalition Army of Conquest, known as Jaish al-Fatah, instead of Islamic State for second straight day, despite Russia's assertions to the contrary; move infuriates United States officials, who insist on prioritizing defeat of Islamic State, and suspect Russia of entering conflict primarily to preserve regime of Bashar al-Assad.

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
keywords.name: organizations

lead_paragraph: This time Russian warplanes may have struck an ISIS-held town as well as anti-government insurgents.

headline.print_headline: New Russian Strikes Appear to Hit Syrian Rebels, Not Islamic State
headline.main: Russia Carries Out Airstrikes in Syria for 2nd Day
